thread.title: Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer
thread.title_full: Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer

author: JIM LITKE
title: Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer
text:
David J. Phillip Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer 
Chicago Cubs manager Joe Maddon yells home after a call during the fifth inning of Game 4 of the National League baseball championship series against the New York Mets Wednesday, Oct. 21, 2015, in Chicago. (AP Photo/David J. Phillip) David Goldman Chicago Cubs' breakout season ends with sweep in NLCS 
A Chicago Cubs fan stays in his seat at Wrigley Field after Game 4 of the National League baseball championship series against the New York Mets Wednesday, Oct. 21, 2015, in Chicago. The Mets won 8-3 to advance to the World Series. (AP Photo/David Goldman) David J. Phillip Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer 
Chicago Cubs' Kyle Schwarber can't catch a ball hit by New York Mets' Wilmer Flores during the first inning of Game 4 of the National League baseball championship series Wednesday, Oct. 21, 2015, in Chicago. (AP Photo/David J. Phillip) David Goldman Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer 
Some Chicago Cubs players wait in the outfield at Wrigley Field before Game 4 of the National League baseball championship series against the New York Mets Wednesday, Oct. 21, 2015, in Chicago. (AP Photo/David Goldman) Posted: Thursday, October 22, 2015 2:41 am Column: Still loveable, Cubs won't be losers for much longer Associated Press | 0 comments 
CHICAGO (AP) — Most years, a night this warm this late in October would feel like a gift. This year, because of a young Cubs team that fought off hibernation until the next-to-last possible moment, it turned out to be more of a mixed blessing. 
The closest thing to a hometown celebration Wednesday night lasted all of a half-minute. It came while the Mets were still celebrating themselves, spilling out of the visiting dugout nearly a half-hour after completing a four-game sweep in the NLCS with an 8-3 win. kAmp4C@DD E96 7:6=5[ E96 rF3D 6>6C865 7C@> E96:C 5F8@FE 2 76H A=2J6CD 2E 2 E:>6[ E6?E2E:G6 2E 7:CDE[ 2?5 E96?
